image.altText: A digger is working on a block of land behind a 'For Sale' sign. The sign has a 'Sold' sticker on it.

props.synopsis: The NT government's new housing incentive program includes three different grants ranging from $10,000 to $50,000, encompassing both first home buyers and existing home owners.

title.children: Australia's most generous housing grant scheme opens in the NT today. Here's what's on offer

image.altText: A large white house with a "for sale" sign in front of it.

props.synopsis: National home prices rose in September, new data shows, but some of the heat continues to come out of the housing market as more owner-occupiers and investors consider selling.

title.children: With 'borrowing capacity still pretty constrained', Australia's house price rises are slowing

image.altText: A man, his wife and their infant son smile at the camera. They are sitting.

props.synopsis: In Robinvale and Ararat, providing housing and community support is proving successful in attracting new residents and leaders say other towns can learn from their experience.

title.children: These regional towns have uncovered a formula to entice migrants to fill worker shortages and stay

image.altText: Police talk to residents in Alice Springs.

props.synopsis: A female police officer was hospitalised in Alice Springs on the weekend after a string of violent incidents allegedly targeting police.

title.children: Claims Alice Springs police being treated like 'community's punching bags' after violent weekend

image.altText: A man and woman stand side-by-side, smiling.

props.synopsis: No puppies, mandatory medical examinations and hard-to-understand financial consequences. Welcome to life inside some of Australia's retirement villages.

title.children: No puppies, no long-term visitors, mandatory medical examinations: Retirement village contracts exposed

image.altText: A plane sits on the runway at an airport. It is white with purple highlights and the word Bonza on the side.

props.synopsis: Investigators are examining why some money destined for a private investment firm's football teams instead went to Bonza. The airline collapsed barely a year after it launched.

title.children: Money-laundering investigation examining the funding of failed airline Bonza

image.altText: A man wearing shorts and sneakers wheeling a suitcase behind him.

props.synopsis: In August, New Zealand's central bank suddenly had to begin cutting as the economy plunged into recession. Many global counterparts have begun asking: Could we be next?

title.children: The great Kiwi rate hike experiment and where it all went wrong

image.altText: Coles and Woolworths branding outside neighbouring supermarkets

props.synopsis: Federal and state treasurers will meet to change planning and zoning laws to end alleged "land banking" by the supermarket giants, where property is purchased and sat on to prevent competitors from entering.

title.children: Coles and Woolworths's alleged land hoarding comes under the microscope, as treasurers seek zoning law changes

image.altText: A man in a bar with a glass of water

props.synopsis: When Sam Goding was in the grips of alcoholism, he says the price of alcohol didn't matter — he'd reach for methylated spirits mixed with soft drink if he had to. He's on the fence about whether plans to remove the NT's alcohol floor price will make a difference.

title.children: Sam would have done anything for a drink. He's on the fence about the NT's alcohol price laws

image.altText: Two chickens stand beside a red bowl.

props.synopsis: Two million Australian chickens have already been killed in the nation's bird flu outbreak — and that's before the deadliest strain of the virus hits our shores.

title.children: Australia's bird flu time bomb is ticking, with scientists and farmers bracing for the worst

image.altText: Xi Jinping gives a little wave next to a Chinese flag

props.synopsis: The bursting of China's economic bubble has exposed deep vulnerabilities in the Chinese Communist Party  — and threatens Xi Jinping's legacy.

title.children: As China turns 75 today, Xi Jinping faces mounting challenges

image.altText: Numerous large tanks seen in an open area

props.synopsis: Israel's defence minister all but confirms plans to launch a ground invasion of Lebanon — although not the timing of it — as the country's military continues to gather near the border.

title.children: US confirms Israel is conducting 'limited operations' in Lebanon as ground invasion appears imminent

image.altText: A drone shot of Tuvalu.

props.synopsis: As rising tides grip Tuvalu, many citizens are considering migration. But what will life look like for those who chose to stay?

title.children: Here's how Tuvaluans determined to stay put are fighting to save their island nation

image.altText: A run down brick property, with a rusty roof

props.synopsis: A run-down convict building was bequeathed to Tasmania's Heritage Council. Following the council's decision to pass on the property, it was snapped up by the then-deputy chair — now an investigation is underway.

title.children: A deceased estate tried to donate this derelict convict building. Its purchase has triggered an investigation

image.altText: A generic composit image of a transmission tower and a smart meter.

props.synopsis: A simmering row between electricity retailers and poles-and-wires companies boils over amid claims consumers are being hurt by "perverse" complex prices.

title.children: Electricity industry at war with itself as retailers unload on 'perverse, impossible' tariffs

image.altText: Fingers on a computer keyboard.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of email addresses, some understood to belong to victims of crime, have been shared in a Victorian courts administrative blunder, leaving at least one victim "very frightened" about the fallout.

title.children: Hundreds of email addresses shared in 'horrific' Victorian victims of crime administrative error

image.altText: Steven Miles wears a green and gold scarf while standing in front of pop-up banners.

props.synopsis: Steven Miles is about to hit the campaign trail to sway voters, but the polls suggest he's still got a lot of convincing to do, writes Leonie Mellor.

title.children: The Queensland election won't be decided in Brisbane — and the polls suggest Steven Miles has a lot of convincing to do

image.altText: A blue sky, many mountain peaks and a river in the foreground,

props.synopsis: Rising a couple of millimetres per year on average, Mt Everest is having a growth spurt. A new study suggests that a "pirated" river thousands of years ago might have given it a boost.

title.children: Why is Mt Everest growing twice as quickly as expected?

image.altText: A man with a world map behind him

props.synopsis: Ryan Routh, 58, entered the plea to five federal charges that include attempted assassination of a major presidential candidate.

title.children: Man charged with attempting to assassinate Donald Trump pleads not guilty

image.altText: An image of a teenager's hand holding a vape.

props.synopsis: Australians aged 18 and over looking to buy a vape without a prescription can now do so legally under changes to national vaping legislation that come into effect today.

title.children: Vapes are now available without a prescription. But not all pharmacies are selling them

image.altText: Side headshot of a young woman speaking

props.synopsis: Sheree Schonian lost control over the length of her skirt, her friends and the food she ate while she was in a 16-year abusive relationship. She is speaking out to help others affected by domestic violence.

title.children: 'Everything was always my fault': Coercive control survivor speaks as new campaign targets abuse

image.altText: A woman's hands hold a smartphone in shadow.

props.synopsis: Tinder, Hinge and other online dating platforms will have six months to become compliant with a code of conduct designed to make the matchmaker apps safer, after years of reported failures to act on sexual assaults enabled by their platforms.

title.children: Dating code will require Tinder, Hinge to act on dangerous users, cooperate with law enforcement

image.altText: A yellow Hezbollah flag, featuring an arm reaching up to a rifle, seen above a sea of people.

props.synopsis: Federal police expect to investigate at least six alleged crimes involving prohibited symbols and chants, after Hezbollah flags were waved at a Melbourne rally calling for ceasefires in Gaza and Lebanon.

title.children: Police investigate 'at least six' reports of crime after Hezbollah flag appears at Melbourne rally

image.altText: A man in a suit sits on a leather lounge, looking professional.

props.synopsis: The special envoy to combat Islamophobia, Aftab Malik, has been appointed by the federal government, months after it named Australia's first anti-Semitism envoy.

title.children: Islamophobia envoy Aftab Malik appointed after months of delay

image.altText: A woman wearing a black scarf reading Quran

props.synopsis: As more details emerge about the Israeli attack that killed Hezbollah's leader in Beirut, analysts say it's likely US-made 2,000 pound "bunker buster" bombs were used in the strikes carried out in the densely populated neighbourhood.

title.children: Israel used US-made 'bunker buster' bombs in attack on Hezbollah's leader, analysts say

image.altText: Power station towers seen on a countryside landscape and cloudy sky.

props.synopsis: The last coal-fired power station in the United Kingdom is officially closing down, book-ending the nearly-150-year history of British coal power.

title.children: UK becomes first G7 nation to end coal power with last plant closure

image.altText: A boy wrapped in a blue blanket stands next to a destroyed building.

props.synopsis: Russia has launched several waves of drone attacks targeting Kyiv, according to Ukraine's military, with air defence units engaged in repelling the strikes for several hours.

title.children: Ukrainian military reports waves of Russian drone attacks on Kyiv

image.altText: Five people sit at a table on stage playing dungeons and dragons

props.synopsis: Dungeons & Dragons games are being played live to packed theatre audiences, including at the Sydney Opera House, as the once-niche pastime becomes mainstream.

title.children: Dungeons & Dragons moves from the dining table to the Sydney Opera House

image.altText: The exterior of a modern-looking school building

props.synopsis: A former Canberra Marist College student is preparing to sue over the canings and other corporal punishments he allegedly received as a young student in the early 1970s.

title.children: Former Marist College student preparing to sue over alleged historic corporal punishment, sexual abuse

image.altText: A large crowd of people on a rugby field.

props.synopsis: The record was previously held by France, who broke it in 2014 with more than 4,000 attempting the haka after a rugby match.

title.children: 'What the heck?' How New Zealand has claimed back the crown for a record haka from France

image.altText: A man standing in a crowd and waves

props.synopsis: After one of the closest-ever leadership races for the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, Japan's incoming Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba says he will call a general election for October 27.

title.children: Japan's incoming PM Ishiba calls election for October 27

image.altText: A court sketch of Terence Kelly at his sentencing for the kidnapping of four-year-old Cleo Smith in WA's outback.

props.synopsis: Terence Kelly fails to get his sentence reduced for abducting four-year-old Cleo Smith from her family's campsite in remote WA three years ago, with a judge rejecting his claim that his mental impairments should have been given greater weight.

title.children: Man who abducted four-year-old Cleo Smith from family tent fails in bid to reduce sentence

image.altText: Errol Gulden and Braeden Campbell look sad after the grand final

props.synopsis: The man who led Sydney to a drought-breaking premiership win in 2005 has called on the club to get more ruthless as it reels from a second grand final thumping in three seasons.

title.children: 'You have to leave': Paul Roos urges Swans to make brutal calls on any players dealing with grand final scarring

image.altText: Sunia Turuva crosses over for a try under pressure

props.synopsis: NRL head of football Graham Annesley attempts to clear some confusion over obstruction calls ahead of Sunday's grand final between the Panthers and Storm.

title.children: 'Our game's not perfect': NRL admits to bunker error after Ivan Cleary blasted video refereeing standards

image.altText: Two young nurses in sunglasses hold cardboard posters protesting nurses pay rates

props.synopsis: NSW Health will begin paying an interim 3 per cent wage increase to nurses and midwives from next year, with the union accepting the recommendations from the Industrial Relations Commission.

title.children: Nurses' union agree to 3 per cent 'good faith' wage increase to halt industrial action during NSW Health negotiations
